newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SA WEEK AHEAD - M3, CREDIT HIGHER, GDP STILL STRONG.
newsitem.headline: SA WEEK AHEAD - M3, CREDIT HIGHER, GDP STILL STRONG.

text.p: South African financial markets will be bombarded this week with a welter of economic indicators including key credit and money supply data, GDP growth numbers and inflation and trade figures.
First in line is the April trade figure, originally scheduled for last week, which will likely be released on Monday at 1200 GMT.

The average of eight forecasts collected predicted another surplus of around 900 million rand from a 1.98 billion rand surplus in March. Expectations are for continuing improvement on a rolling three-month basis as the pace of export growth picks up relative to that of imports, economists said.
The trade numbers will be followed on Wednesday at 1500 GMT by the Reserve Bank's closely watched money supply and private sector credit extension data.
The credit figure continues to be an important indicator for interest rates and came in lower-than-expected in March, fueling hope that the consumer credit binge was finally starting to fizzle out.

Eleven economists polled by Reuters on Friday forecast both April money supply and credit to climb, calling for a 16.7 percent year-on-year rise in money supply growth from a preliminary 16.39 percent increase in March.
Growth in credit extension was seen rising 16.4 percent from 15.96 percent previously.
The credit number would be pushed higher by technical factors, with the figure being calculated from a very low base month the previous year, economists said.

"The pace of consumer spending is slowing so you'll see a slowdown in the month-on-month rate of increase but because of the low base it is likely to increase on a year-on-year basis," said Rand Merchant Bank (RMB) treasury economist Julia Roy.
While there were signs that consumers were starting to borrow at a slower rate, economists said corporate credit demand remained strong.
On money supply, they said the figure would be held up by capital inflows on the balance of payments but more would depend on the credit demand side.
"Technical factors will again push the figure higher," one noted.
Also due out on Wednesday is the April inflation rate which is scheduled for 0900 GMT.
April will likely confirm that consumer inflation will peak below 10 percent, after much talk at the beginning of the year of the unfavourable spectre of double-digit inflation.
Economists polled forecast the consumer price index would remain flat from the March figure at 0.6 percent month-on-month or 9.6 percent year-on-year, the first dip in 11 months.

"The good news is that the April figure should either confirm that the 9.8 percent (year-on-year rise) in February was the peak or that, if the figure surprises on the high side, that will represent the peak," said RMB's Roy.
Sandra Gordon of Syfrets saw a peak of 0.8 percent month-on-month or 9.8 percent year-on-year in April with inflation expected to taper off to around 9.4 percent in May.
The last key number coming up on Thursday at 0730 GMT is first quarter gross domestic product (GDP) growth.
The consensus was for GDP to rise a seasonally adjusted and annualised 2.5 percent in the first quarter from a 3.3 percent fourth quarter rise last year.
"Generally not a bad quarter and manufacturing production was very strong in the first quarter," said Nedcor's Dennis Dykes.
Consumer spending had held up mainly because of spending on durables, in particular motor cars, he said.
From the output point of view agriculture would still have done reasonably well while mining did relatively badly due to gold mining production coming off.
"But I think it's a bit deceptive and the second quarter is going to come off quite sharply with manufacturing starting to show signs of flagging out a bit after the rand induced boom," Dykes said.
-- Johannesburg newsroom 27 11 482 1003
